Questions

QTextInput

class question.QTextInput(layout='force-directed', feedback=False, node_prefix='', label_style='none', data=None, data_type='string')

Enter a text input value.

The student can enter any string as their answer.

layout

“force-directed” [default] | “circle” | “grid” | “bipartite” Determines the layout style for the graph.

Type

str

feedback

If True, use the generate_feedback() method, otherwise use the generate_solutions() method for verifying answers.

Type

bool

node_prefix

A prefix to prepend onto vertex labels.

Type

str

label_style

“none” [default] | “math” Determines the style for node labels.

Type

str

data

Persistent storage. You can set data to anything that is JSON serializable, and it will still be accessible if/when the generate_feedback() method is called.

Type

None | any

data_type

“string” [default] | “integer” If set to “integer”, client-side type-checking will be used to ensure the user only enters an integer value.

Type

str

abstract QTextInput.generate_data() → list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]

Generates a list of NetworkX graphs for the question.

Returns

graphs – A list of NetworkX Graphs.

Return type

[networkx Graph]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QTextInput.generate_question(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → str

Generates the wording of the question.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

description – The question description.

Return type

str

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QTextInput.generate_solutions(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → list[str]

Generates a list of possible solutions.

Each solution in the list should be a string that is an acceptable answer. The student’s answer will be verified by comparing it with each solution until an equal string is found.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

solutions – A list of all possible solutions. Each solution is itself a string.

Return type

[str]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QTextInput.generate_feedback(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph], answer: str) -> (<class 'bool'>, <class 'str'>)

Generates a message to be displayed when the solution has been submitted.

Parameters

  • graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

  • answer (str) – The student’s choice of answer, a string.

Returns

(result, explanation) – A pair: whether the answer is correct, and the message to be displayed.

Return type

(bool, str)

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

QMultipleChoice

class question.QMultipleChoice(layout='force-directed', feedback=False, node_prefix='', label_style='none', data=None, single_selection=False)

Multiple choice question.

This presents the student with a list of options to choose from. Depending on the single_selection setting, they will either be rendered as radio buttons or checkboxes.

For this question type, the generate_solutions method must be implemented. This is because it is used to generate the actual multiple choice options.

layout

“force-directed” [default] | “circle” | “grid” | “bipartite” Determines the layout style for the graph.

Type

str

feedback

If True, use the generate_feedback() method, otherwise use the generate_solutions() method for verifying answers.

Type

bool

node_prefix

A prefix to prepend onto vertex labels.

Type

str

label_style

“none” [default] | “math” Determines the style for node labels.

Type

str

data

Persistent storage. You can set data to anything that is JSON serializable, and it will still be accessible if/when the generate_feedback() method is called.

Type

None | any

single_selection

If True, the user can only select a single option (i.e. radio button). Otherwise, the user can select multiple options (i.e. checkbox).

Type

bool

abstract QMultipleChoice.generate_data() → list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]

Generates a list of NetworkX graphs for the question.

Returns

graphs – A list of NetworkX Graphs.

Return type

[networkx Graph]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QMultipleChoice.generate_question(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → str

Generates the wording of the question.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

description – The question description.

Return type

str

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QMultipleChoice.generate_solutions(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → list[[<class 'str'>, <class 'bool'>]]

Generates a list of the options for the question.

This method must be implemented, regardless of the feedback setting. However, if feedback is set to True, the boolean values returned are irrelevant. This is because the generate_feedback() method will be used to verify the student’s answer instead.

When the options are shown to the student, they are all initialised to False, i.e. unselected. On submission, these truth values are compared to the ones you set here.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

solutions – A list of possible solutions. Each solution is itself a pair: the unique text displayed for that option, and whether this option is a correct choice.

Return type

[[str, bool]]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QMultipleChoice.generate_feedback(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph], answer: list[[<class 'str'>, <class 'bool'>]]) -> (<class 'bool'>, <class 'str'>)

Generates a message to be displayed when the solution has been submitted.

Parameters

  • graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

  • answer ([[str, bool]]) – The student’s choice of answer. This is a copy of the options generated by the generate_solutions() method, but with the student’s selections represented as True values.

Returns

(result, explanation) – A pair: whether the answer is correct, and the message to be displayed.

Return type

(bool, str)

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

QVertexSet

class question.QVertexSet(layout='force-directed', feedback=False, node_prefix='', label_style='none', data=None, selection_limit=- 1)

Select a vertex set.

The student selects a set of vertices in the graph by tapping on nodes. Their answer is represented as a list of nodes, e.g. [5, 2, 7].

layout

“force-directed” [default] | “circle” | “grid” | “bipartite” Determines the layout style for the graph.

Type

str

feedback

If True, use the generate_feedback() method, otherwise use the generate_solutions() method for verifying answers.

Type

bool

node_prefix

A prefix to prepend onto vertex labels.

Type

str

label_style

“none” [default] | “math” Determines the style for node labels.

Type

str

data

Persistent storage. You can set data to anything that is JSON serializable, and it will still be accessible if/when the generate_feedback() method is called.

Type

None | any

selection_limit

Maximum number of nodes the user is allowed to select. Default is -1 (no limit).

Type

int

abstract QVertexSet.generate_data() → list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]

Generates a list of NetworkX graphs for the question.

Returns

graphs – A list of NetworkX Graphs.

Return type

[networkx Graph]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QVertexSet.generate_question(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → str

Generates the wording of the question.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

description – The question description.

Return type

str

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QVertexSet.generate_solutions(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → list[[<class 'int'>]]

Generates a list of possible solutions.

Each solution is itself a list of nodes. For example, the return value could be

[[5, 2, 7],

[1, 2, 6]]

Indicating there are 2 possible solutions: the set [5, 2, 7] and the set [1, 2, 6].

The student’s answer is verified by comparing it against each solution. The answer and solution are compared as sets, so order is irrelevant.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

solutions – A list of all possible solutions. Each solution is itself a list of nodes.

Return type

[[int]]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QVertexSet.generate_feedback(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph], answer: list[int]) -> (<class 'bool'>, <class 'str'>)

Generates a message to be displayed when the solution has been submitted.

Parameters

  • graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

  • answer ([[int]]) – The student’s choice of answer, a list of vertices.

Returns

(result, explanation) – A pair: whether the answer is correct, and the message to be displayed.

Return type

(bool, str)

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

QEdgeSet

class question.QEdgeSet(layout='force-directed', feedback=False, node_prefix='', label_style='none', data=None, selection_limit=- 1)

Select a set of edges.

The student selects edges by tapping on them in the graph. Their answer is represented as a list of pairs, e.g. [[0, 1], [3, 4], [2, 3]].

layout

“force-directed” [default] | “circle” | “grid” | “bipartite” Determines the layout style for the graph.

Type

str

feedback

If True, use the generate_feedback() method, otherwise use the generate_solutions() method for verifying answers.

Type

bool

node_prefix

A prefix to prepend onto vertex labels.

Type

str

label_style

“none” [default] | “math” Determines the style for node labels.

Type

str

data

Persistent storage. You can set data to anything that is JSON serializable, and it will still be accessible if/when the generate_feedback() method is called.

Type

None | any

selection_limit

The maximum number of edges the user is allowed to select. Default is -1 (no limit).

Type

int

abstract QEdgeSet.generate_data() → list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]

Return type

[networkx Graph]

Raises

description – The question description.

Return type

str

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QEdgeSet.generate_solutions(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → list[list[list[int, int]]]

Generates a list of possible solutions.

Each solution is itself a list of edge pairs. For example, the return value could be

[[[0, 1], [3, 4], [2, 3]],

[[0, 1], [2, 3]]]

Indicating there are 2 possible solutions: the set of edges [0, 1], [3, 4], [2, 3] and the set of edges [0, 1], [2, 3].

The student’s answer is verified by comparing it against each solution. The answer and solution are compared as sets, so order is irrelevant. When comparing individual edges, order is only important when the graph is directed.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

solutions – A list of all possible solutions. Each solution is a list of edge pairs.

Return type

[[[int, int]]]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QEdgeSet.generate_feedback(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph], answer: list[list[int, int]]) -> (<class 'bool'>, <class 'str'>)

Generates a message to be displayed when the solution has been submitted.

Parameters

  • graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

  • answer ([[int, int]]) – The student’s choice of answer, a list of edges.

Returns

(result, explanation) – A pair: whether the answer is correct, and the message to be displayed.

Return type

(bool, str)

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

QSelectPath

class question.QSelectPath(layout='force-directed', feedback=False, node_prefix='', label_style='none', data=None)

Select a path in a given graph.

The student will select the path by tapping on nodes in the graph. The answer is represented as a list of integers, e.g. [0, 3, 5, 2].

The question will only allow the student to select a valid simple path in the graph.

layout

“force-directed” [default] | “circle” | “grid” | “bipartite” Determines the layout style for the graph.

Type

str

feedback

If True, use the generate_feedback() method, otherwise use the generate_solutions() method for verifying answers.

Type

bool

node_prefix

A prefix to prepend onto vertex labels.

Type

str

label_style

“none” [default] | “math” Determines the style for node labels.

Type

str

data

Persistent storage. You can set data to anything that is JSON serializable, and it will still be accessible if/when the generate_feedback() method is called.

Type

None | any

abstract QSelectPath.generate_data() → list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]

Generates a list of NetworkX graphs for the question.

Returns

graphs – A list of NetworkX Graphs.

Return type

[networkx Graph]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QSelectPath.generate_question(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → str

Generates the wording of the question.

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question.

Returns

description – The question description.

Return type

str

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

abstract QSelectPath.generate_solutions(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph]) → list[list[int]]

Generates a list of possible solutions.

Each solution is itself a list of vertices. For example, the return value could be

[[0, 3, 5, 2],

[0, 3, 4, 2]]

Indicating there are 2 possible solutions: the path [0, 3, 5, 2] and the path [0, 3, 4, 2].

Parameters

graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The NetworkX graphs used in the question. They will be labelled in-order as G1, G2, …

Returns

solutions – A list of all possible solutions. Each solution is itself a list of nodes.

Return type

[[int]]

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented

Notes

The student’s answer is compared against each path in the solutions until a match is found. The answer is only considered to be correct if the two lists are identical in size and order. i.e. an answer of [0, 1, 2] would fail against a list of solutions of [[0, 2, 1], [0, 1, 2, 3]].

abstract QSelectPath.generate_feedback(graphs: list[networkx.classes.graph.Graph], answer: list[int]) -> (<class 'bool'>, <class 'str'>)

Generates a message to be displayed when the solution has been submitted.

Parameters

  • graphs ([networkx Graph]) – The networkx graphs used in the question.

  • answer ([int]) – The student’s choice of answer, a list of vertices.

Returns

(result, explanation) – A pair: whether the answer is correct, and the message to be displayed.

Return type

(bool, str)

Raises

NotImplementedError – If the method is not implemented
